While I understand your point that most Americans live within commuting distance of universities, I partially disagree with your claim that "Students should live off campus." 

Commuting may seem like a practical option for many due to their proximity to the university, but we shouldn't generalize this as the best option for all students. While commuting might save on housing costs, it may not always contribute positively to their academic performance and overall college experience.

Firstly, frequent commuting can lead to more stress and fatigue, and these could detrimentally affect a student's focus and studies. Secondly, living on-campus provides students with a conducive study environment, easy access to university facilities, increased social interaction and a deep sense of belongingness to the university community.

Hence, the decision of whether students should live on or off campus should be determined individually, considering multiple factors such as commuting time, financial status, academic performance, and social preferences.

I can appreciate the advantages you've enumerated about living off-campus, such as fostering independence, experiencing real-world scenarios, diversifying interactions, and the possibility of finding cost-effective housing. Your point is well taken that not all universities can accommodate all their students on-campus. 

However, I continue to have reservations in universally agreeing that "Students should live off campus". This is because some considerations could potentially undermine the benefits you have proposed. 

For instance, the financial aspect. This idea presumes that off-campus housing is universally more affordable, but this isn't always the case. Rental prices can fluctuate greatly depending on the location and proximity of the housing to the university. Sometimes, on-campus housing can save students' money considering utilities, internet, and other costs are often included in the fees.

Then comes the aspect of independence. While independence can be gained from living off-campus, not all students are ready for this level of responsibility. Some students might become isolated or might struggle with managing concurrent demands of household chores, part-time jobs, financial management, and academic stress.

Furthermore, as for experiencing real-world situations and diversity, on-campus life also provides plenty of opportunities for this. Universities typically attract students from diverse cultural, social, and economic backgrounds. On-campus students encounter this diversity daily.

Thus, although off-campus living absolutely offers merits, I cannot fully endorse the claim of "Students should live off campus". The decision should remain as a matter of personal preference based on individual circumstances, logistical considerations, and preparedness for off-campus living.
